DataElement.preferredName: Psychiatric Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Reaction Index Assessment Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Symptoms, physical examination results, and/or laboratory test results related to mental health.:Published by the American Psychiatric Association, the DSM is a listing of currently recognized mental health disorders and their diagnostic criteria, for children and adults. It includes statistical information on etiology, incidence, prevalence, age of onset and prognosis. The 4th edition was published in 1994. As new information becomes available subsequent editions are published._An anxiety disorder precipitated by an experience of intense fear or horror while exposed to a traumatic (especially life-threatening) event. The disorder is characterized by intrusive recurring thoughts or images of the traumatic event; avoidance of anything associated with the event; a state of hyperarousal and diminished emotional responsiveness. These symptoms are present for at least one month and the disorder is usually long-term._A response generated by a stimulus._A numerical scale used to compare variables with one another or with some reference number; a number used to select an element of a list, vector, array or other sequence._a free text field to specify information on the evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease

Property.preferredName: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder Reaction Index
Property.preferredDefinition: Published by the American Psychiatric Association, the DSM is a listing of currently recognized mental health disorders and their diagnostic criteria, for children and adults. It includes statistical information on etiology, incidence, prevalence, age of onset and prognosis. The 4th edition was published in 1994. As new information becomes available subsequent editions are published.:A class of traumatic stress disorders with symptoms that last more than one month. There are various forms of post-traumatic stress disorder, depending on the time of onset and the duration of these stress symptoms. In the acute form, the duration of the symptoms is between 1 to 3 months. In the chronic form, symptoms last more than 3 months. With delayed onset, symptoms develop more than 6 months after the traumatic event.:A response generated by a stimulus.:A numerical scale used to compare variables with one another or with some reference number; a number used to select an element of a list, vector, array or other sequence.

Concepts.longName: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 4th Edition
Concepts.definition: Published by the American Psychiatric Association, the DSM is a listing of currently recognized mental health disorders and their diagnostic criteria, for children and adults. It includes statistical information on etiology, incidence, prevalence, age of onset and prognosis. The 4th edition was published in 1994. As new information becomes available subsequent editions are published.

An anxiety disorder precipitated by an experience of intense fear or horror while exposed to a traumatic (especially life-threatening) event. The disorder is characterized by intrusive recurring thoughts or images of the traumatic event; avoidance of anything associated with the event; a state of hyperarousal and diminished emotional responsiveness. These symptoms are present for at least one month and the disorder is usually long-term.
A response generated by a stimulus.
A numerical scale used to compare variables with one another or with some reference number; a number used to select an element of a list, vector, array or other sequence.
